facts: Afghanistan is landlocked, but it sits at a crossroads where Central and South Asia collide.
The Hindu Kush mountains slice through the country and make travel famously difficult.
Kabul is one of the world’s highest capital cities, sitting in a mountain valley.
Afghanistan has had camel caravans, Silk Road trade routes, and empires passing through for centuries.
The country is known for deep-blue lapis lazuli, mined there since ancient times.
A narrow finger of land called the Wakhan Corridor stretches toward China like a geographic plot twist.
Dari and Pashto are the two main official languages, and you’ll hear many more local languages too.
Traditional carpets from Afghanistan are famous for dense patterns and hard-wearing wool.
Much of the country is arid or semi-arid, so water and irrigation shape where people live.
Afghanistan uses a unique time offset: UTC+4:30, because why be ordinary?
Albania has both Adriatic and Ionian coastlines, so it’s basically a beach country hiding in plain sight.
Tirana is the capital, and its colorful buildings were part vibe upgrade, part civic project.
Albania is one of Europe’s most mountainous countries, with dramatic peaks packed into a small area.
The Albanian flag is a black double-headed eagle on red, and it looks like it means business.
Bunkers are scattered across the country from the Cold War era, and some are now cafés or museums.
The Albanian language is its own branch of Indo-European, with no close sibling language next door.
Lake Ohrid, shared with North Macedonia, is one of Europe’s oldest and deepest lakes.
The Riviera in the south has clear water and steep coastal roads that feel like a movie chase scene.
Albania has ancient ruins from Greek and Roman times, including sites like Butrint.
If you like your geography spicy, Albania has mountains, beaches, and rivers all competing for attention.
Algeria is Africa’s largest country by area, and a huge chunk of it is Sahara Desert.
The capital, Algiers, sits on the Mediterranean with white buildings that earned it the nickname ‘Algiers the White.’
The Sahara isn’t just dunes; Algeria has rocky plateaus, salt flats, and surreal sandstone landscapes too.
Algeria has ancient Roman ruins, including Timgad, which looks like a city plan drawn with a ruler.
The Tassili n’Ajjer region is famous for prehistoric rock art showing animals and people from greener eras.
Arabic is the official language, and Tamazight (Berber) is also recognized nationally.
Algeria’s coastline is long, but the population is concentrated in the north where the climate is milder.
The Atlas Mountains run through the country and act like a climate boundary line.
Algeria is a major producer of natural gas, and energy exports are a big part of its economy.
If you’re counting time zones, Algeria runs on UTC+1, aligned with much of Western/Central Europe.
American Samoa is an unincorporated U.S. territory in the South Pacific, made of volcanic islands.
Its main island, Tutuila, has steep green mountains that drop straight into the ocean.
Pago Pago is famous for having one of the best natural harbors in the Pacific.
American Samoa sits just east of the International Date Line, so it’s often “yesterday” compared to nearby Samoa.
The territory is known for strong Polynesian culture, especially the fa’a Samoa way of life.
You can find giant fruit bats (flying foxes) in the region, which are both cute and slightly unhinged.
It uses U.S. dollars, but the vibe is island-Pacific rather than mainland-American.
The National Park of American Samoa protects rainforest, reefs, and coastline across multiple islands.
American Samoa has no snakes native to the islands, which is honestly a vacation selling point.
Its time zone is UTC−11, which is basically ‘time travel’ compared to Europe.
Andorra is a tiny country tucked between France and Spain in the Pyrenees mountains.
It’s one of the world’s microstates, but it has serious ski resort energy.
Andorra la Vella is the capital and one of the highest capital cities in Europe.
Andorra has two co-princes as heads of state: one from France and one linked to Spain’s side (via the Bishop of Urgell).
Catalan is the official language, which makes Andorra feel culturally distinct from its neighbors.
The country is famous for duty-free shopping, especially for perfume, alcohol, and electronics.
Andorra is mountainous enough that scenic drives come with dramatic hairpin turns as standard.
It’s not in the EU, but it uses the euro, because geography likes loopholes.
Hiking trails in summer swap out the ski crowd for mountain-lake people in sensible boots.
Andorra has no airport or railway inside the country, so you arrive by road like it’s a secret level.
Angola sits on Africa’s southwest coast and has a mix of beaches, savanna, and highlands.
Luanda is the capital, and it’s known for a dramatic coastline and big-city bustle.
Angola includes the Cabinda exclave, separated from the rest of the country by a slice of the DRC.
Portuguese is the official language, a legacy of Angola’s colonial history.
The country has the giant Kalandula Falls, one of Africa’s largest waterfalls by volume.
Angola’s landscape ranges from the Namib Desert edge in the south to lush forests in the north.
The ‘black giant sable antelope’ is an iconic Angolan animal and a national symbol-level flex.
Angola is a major oil producer, especially offshore, which shapes much of its economy.
The country has long Atlantic beaches, but also rugged inland plateaus that feel wildly different.
Angola runs on UTC+1, so it shares a clock with places like Portugal in winter.
Anguilla is a British Overseas Territory in the Caribbean, known for bright water and pale sand.
It’s long and narrow, and the name literally means ‘eel’ in Spanish, because the shape is that dramatic.
The capital is The Valley, which sounds like a band name, not a capital city.
Anguilla has a reefy coastline that’s great for snorkeling, with shipwrecks and coral gardens.
The island is low-lying and mostly flat, so your ‘mountain hike’ is basically a brisk walk.
English is the main language, with local Caribbean rhythms in how it’s spoken.
Anguilla uses the Eastern Caribbean dollar, shared with several nearby islands.
It’s a small place, so beaches feel like the main national infrastructure.
Boat days matter here: nearby cays and little sandbars are part of the Anguilla experience.
It sits in the Atlantic time zone region, running on UTC−4 year-round.
Antarctica is a continent and the world’s largest desert, because it gets very little precipitation.
Antarctica has solid land under its ice sheet, with mountains and valleys buried below.
Antarctica is the only place with wild penguins, and it has zero polar bears.
The Antarctic ice holds most of Earth’s fresh water, locked up as ice rather than lakes.
Winds can be ferocious, including katabatic winds that pour down from the interior like a cold tantrum.
There are no permanent residents, only rotating scientists and support crews at research stations.
Parts of Antarctica are so cold and dry they’re used as Mars analog test sites.
The South Pole is on Antarctica, but it’s not the coldest spot on the continent every day of the year.
Some Antarctic valleys are almost ice-free, because conditions are too harsh for snow to stick around.
Antarctica is governed by international treaty rules, not by any one country.
Antigua and Barbuda is a Caribbean nation made of two main islands and a sprinkle of smaller ones.
Antigua is famous for beaches, with locals joking it has one for every day of the year.
Barbuda is flatter and quieter, and it’s known for long pink-tinged sand beaches.
The capital is St. John’s, with a colorful waterfront and a huge cathedral presence.
The islands sit in the hurricane belt, so storm seasons shape architecture and planning.
English is the official language, but you’ll hear Antiguan and Barbudan Creole in daily life.
Sailing is big here, and Antigua hosts major yachting events that bring serious boat glamour.
Frigate birds are a star attraction, especially around Barbuda’s bird sanctuary areas.
The national flag has a rising sun motif that basically screams ‘tropical sunrise marketing.’
It uses the Eastern Caribbean dollar, shared with several nearby island nations.
Argentina stretches from near the tropics down toward Antarctica, so its climates range wildly.
Buenos Aires is the capital, and it’s famous for tango, late dinners, and serious café culture.
Patagonia in the south has glaciers, wind, and landscapes that look like Earth on hard mode.
Argentina is home to Aconcagua, the highest mountain in the Americas.
The country has one of the world’s biggest wine regions, especially around Mendoza at the Andes foothills.
Iguazú Falls, on the border with Brazil, is a wall of water that feels unreal in person.
Argentina has a strong football culture, and stadium energy can be absolutely volcanic.
The pampas are huge grasslands that shaped the ‘gaucho’ cowboy tradition.
Spanish is the main language, and the local accent in parts of Argentina is instantly recognizable.
Argentina uses multiple time zones in practice, but officially runs on UTC−3.
Armenia is a landlocked country in the South Caucasus with mountains everywhere you look.
Yerevan is one of the world’s oldest continuously inhabited cities, and it has a pink-stone glow at sunset.
Mount Ararat is the iconic mountain in Armenian culture, even though it sits just across the border in Turkey.
Armenia was the first state to adopt Christianity as a state religion, way back in the early 4th century.
The Armenian alphabet is its own script, created in the 5th century and still used today.
Lake Sevan is a huge high-altitude lake that acts like the country’s inland sea.
Apricots are deeply tied to Armenian identity, and even the scientific name hints at that connection.
Armenian monasteries are often perched dramatically on cliffs, like they were designed for postcards.
The country sits in a seismic zone, so earthquakes are part of its geological reality.
Armenia’s time zone is UTC+4, aligning it with parts of the wider Caucasus region.
Aruba is a Caribbean island with a dry climate, so it’s sunny more often than your group chat thinks is fair.
It’s a constituent country within the Kingdom of the Netherlands, with its own local government.
Oranjestad is the capital, known for pastel Dutch-Caribbean architecture and a busy cruise port.
Aruba sits outside the main hurricane belt, which is a big reason it’s a year-round tourist magnet.
The island is famous for divi-divi trees that grow bent from constant trade winds like natural weather vanes.
Papiamento is widely spoken, a creole language blending Portuguese, Spanish, Dutch, and more.
Aruba uses the Aruban florin, and U.S. dollars are also commonly accepted.
The coastline flips between calm turquoise beaches and rougher, rocky shores on the opposite side.
Arikok National Park covers a big slice of the island, with caves, cacti, and volcanic formations.
Aruba runs on UTC−4, with no daylight saving time drama.
Australia is both a country and a continent, which is an efficiency move other places didn’t commit to.
The Great Barrier Reef is the world’s largest coral reef system and it’s visible from space in parts.
Australia is home to marsupials like kangaroos and koalas, plus monotremes like the platypus that look invented.
The country has more than one desert, and most Australians live close to the coast anyway.
Canberra is the capital, chosen as a compromise between Sydney and Melbourne, which is very on-brand politics.
Australia has the world’s oldest continuous living cultures, with Indigenous nations spanning the continent.
The Outback covers huge distances, and road trips come with “bring water” energy.
Australia has snow in the Alps, tropical rainforests in the north, and temperate forests in the south.
The Southern Cross on the flag is a real constellation used for navigation in the Southern Hemisphere.
Australia spans multiple time zones, and daylight saving makes it extra confusing on purpose.
Austria is a landlocked country in Central Europe dominated by the Alps.
Vienna was once the capital of a massive empire stretching across Europe.
Austria is famous for classical music, especially composers like Mozart and Strauss.
About two-thirds of the country is mountainous, making skiing a national pastime.
The Danube River flows through Austria on its way to the Black Sea.
Austria consistently ranks among the world’s most livable countries.
German is the official language, but Austrian German has its own flavor.
Coffeehouse culture in Austria is so important it’s officially protected.
Austria uses the euro and is part of the European Union.
Despite the mountains, Austria has flat wine-growing regions in the east.
Azerbaijan sits at the crossroads of Eastern Europe and Western Asia.
It borders the Caspian Sea, which is the world’s largest inland body of water.
Baku, the capital, mixes medieval walls with ultra-modern skyscrapers.
Azerbaijan is nicknamed the Land of Fire due to natural gas flames.
Mud volcanoes are common here, and Azerbaijan has more than any other country.
The country has both deserts and snowy mountain regions.
Azerbaijan uses the manat as its currency.
Chess is extremely popular and widely taught to children.
The Caucasus Mountains shape much of the country’s landscape.
Azerbaijan runs on UTC+4 with no daylight saving time.
Bahrain is a small island nation in the Persian Gulf.
It is connected to Saudi Arabia by a long causeway bridge.
Manama is the capital and a major financial hub in the region.
Bahrain has almost no natural freshwater rivers.
Pearl diving was historically a major industry before oil.
It is one of the most densely populated countries in the world.
Arabic is the official language, and English is widely spoken.
Bahrain experiences extremely hot summers.
The country uses the Bahraini dinar, one of the world’s strongest currencies.
Bahrain operates on UTC+3.
Bangladesh is one of the most densely populated countries on Earth.
It sits on the massive delta of the Ganges and Brahmaputra rivers.
Dhaka is the capital and one of the world’s largest cities.
Flooding plays a major role in shaping the landscape and agriculture.
Rice and fish are central to everyday life and cuisine.
The Sundarbans mangrove forest is home to Bengal tigers.
Bangladesh gained independence in 1971.
Bengali is the official language and one of the most spoken languages globally.
Much of the country is only a few meters above sea level.
Bangladesh uses UTC+6.
Barbados is an island nation in the eastern Caribbean.
It sits outside the main hurricane belt, which helps tourism.
Bridgetown is the capital and a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Barbados is made mostly of coral limestone rather than volcanic rock.
The island has a strong cricket culture inherited from Britain.
English is the official language, with a local Bajan dialect.
Barbados became a republic in 2021.
The east coast faces the Atlantic and has rougher waves.
The west coast has calmer waters and sandy beaches.
Barbados uses UTC−4 year-round.
Belarus is a landlocked country in Eastern Europe.
It is known for vast forests and thousands of lakes.
Minsk is the capital and largest city.
Belarus has one of Europe’s largest remaining primeval forests.
The country has flat terrain with few natural borders.
Belarusian and Russian are both official languages.
Bison are a national symbol and protected species.
Much of the country experiences cold, snowy winters.
Belarus uses its own currency, the Belarusian ruble.
The country operates on UTC+3.
Belgium is a small country with an outsized global influence.
Brussels hosts major European Union institutions.
Belgium has three official languages: Dutch, French, and German.
The country is famous for chocolate, waffles, and fries.
Belgium has one of the world’s densest rail networks.
It played a major role in early European industrialization.
Belgium is mostly flat, especially in the north.
The Ardennes region in the south is hilly and forested.
Belgium is a constitutional monarchy.
It runs on Central European Time.
Belize is the only Central American country with English as its official language.
It borders the Caribbean Sea and has extensive coral reefs.
The Belize Barrier Reef is the second-largest in the world.
Belmopan is the capital, built inland to avoid hurricanes.
Belize has dense rainforests with jaguars and howler monkeys.
Mayan ruins are scattered throughout the country.
The Great Blue Hole is a famous underwater sinkhole.
Belize has a low population density compared to its neighbors.
Multiple cultures coexist, including Maya, Creole, and Garifuna.
Belize uses UTC−6.
Benin is a West African country along the Gulf of Guinea.
It is considered the birthplace of the Vodun religion.
Porto-Novo is the official capital, while Cotonou is the largest city.
Benin was once part of the powerful Kingdom of Dahomey.
The country has a narrow shape stretching north to south.
French is the official language.
Much of Benin’s economy is based on agriculture.
The coast is low-lying and prone to erosion.
Benin has savannas in the north and forests in the south.
It operates on UTC+1.
Bermuda is a British Overseas Territory in the North Atlantic.
It is famous for pink-sand beaches.
Bermuda is not actually in the Caribbean.
Hamilton is the capital, despite being quite small.
The islands sit on a coral platform, not volcanic rock.
Bermuda Triangle legends are associated with the region.
Shorts are accepted business attire in Bermuda.
There are no rivers or freshwater lakes on the islands.
Bermuda uses the Bermudian dollar, pegged to the US dollar.
It runs on UTC−4.
Bhutan is a Himalayan country known for dramatic mountain scenery.
It measures progress using Gross National Happiness.
Thimphu is one of the few capitals without traffic lights.
Bhutan tightly controls tourism to protect its culture.
The country is largely forested and carbon negative.
Buddhism strongly influences daily life and architecture.
Many buildings follow traditional design rules by law.
Bhutan has elevations ranging from subtropical plains to high peaks.
The national sport is archery.
Bhutan operates on UTC+6.
Bolivia has two capitals: La Paz and Sucre.
La Paz is the highest administrative capital in the world.
Bolivia is landlocked but once had a Pacific coastline.
The country contains part of the Andes Mountains.
Salar de Uyuni is the world’s largest salt flat.
Bolivia has a large Indigenous population.
The Amazon rainforest covers much of the north.
Spanish and several Indigenous languages are official.
Lake Titicaca is the highest navigable lake in the world.
Bolivia uses UTC−4.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is located in the western Balkans.
It has a very short coastline on the Adriatic Sea.
Sarajevo is the capital and has Ottoman and Austro-Hungarian influences.
The country is mostly mountainous.
Bosnia has one of Europe’s last primeval forests.
Three major ethnic groups shape the culture.
The old bridge of Mostar is a national symbol.
Coffee culture is deeply ingrained in daily life.
Bosnian, Croatian, and Serbian are all official languages.
It uses Central European Time.
Botswana is a landlocked country in southern Africa.
Much of its territory is covered by the Kalahari Desert.
The Okavango Delta is a massive inland wetland.
Botswana is known for strong wildlife conservation.
Gaborone is the capital and largest city.
Diamonds play a major role in the economy.
The country has one of Africa’s most stable democracies.
Elephants are especially numerous in Botswana.
English is the official language.
Botswana operates on UTC+2.
Brazil is the largest country in South America.
It contains most of the Amazon rainforest.
Brasília was purpose-built as the capital.
Brazil has the world’s largest Portuguese-speaking population.
The country has more biodiversity than any other.
Football is a major part of national identity.
Brazil’s coastline stretches for thousands of kilometers.
The Amazon River system dominates the north.
Brazil spans multiple climate zones.
Brazil runs mainly on UTC−3.
The British Virgin Islands are a UK territory in the Caribbean.
They consist of dozens of islands and cays.
Road Town is the capital, located on Tortola.
Sailing is one of the main attractions.
The islands have clear water and coral reefs.
English is the official language.
The US dollar is the official currency.
Many islands are mountainous despite their small size.
The BVI are popular for island-hopping.
They use UTC−4.
Brunei is a small country on the island of Borneo.
It is one of the wealthiest countries in Southeast Asia.
Oil and gas dominate the economy.
Bandar Seri Begawan is the capital.
The Sultan lives in one of the world’s largest palaces.
Islam plays a central role in public life.
Large areas of rainforest are protected.
Brunei has a small population.
The country is divided into two separate land areas.
Brunei uses UTC+8.
Bulgaria is located in southeastern Europe.
It borders the Black Sea to the east.
Sofia is one of Europe’s oldest capital cities.
Bulgaria uses the Cyrillic alphabet.
The country has both mountains and fertile plains.
Rose oil production is a national specialty.
Bulgaria has ancient Thracian archaeological sites.
The climate ranges from continental to Mediterranean.
Yogurt is a staple food with local bacterial strains.
Bulgaria runs on UTC+2.
Burkina Faso is a landlocked country in West Africa.
Its name means ‘Land of Upright People.’
Ouagadougou is the capital city.
The country lies mostly in the Sahel region.
Music and film festivals are culturally important.
French is the official language.
Agriculture employs much of the population.
The landscape is mostly flat savanna.
Burkina Faso has a tropical climate.
It operates on UTC+0.
Burundi is a small landlocked country in East Africa.
It lies near Lake Tanganyika, one of the world’s deepest lakes.
Gitega is the political capital.
The country has hilly terrain and a mild climate.
Coffee is a major export crop.
Kirundi is spoken by nearly the entire population.
Burundi is one of Africa’s most densely populated countries.
Drumming traditions are internationally recognized.
The Nile’s southern sources are near Burundi.
Burundi uses UTC+2.
Cabo Verde is an island nation off West Africa, famous for morna music and singer Cesária Évora.
The islands were uninhabited until Portuguese settlement, so Cabo Verde has no Indigenous population history.
Cabo Verde’s culture blends African rhythms with Portuguese influences in music, food, and language.
Many Cabo Verdeans live abroad, making remittances a key part of the national economy.
The country is known for dramatic volcanic landscapes and consistently windy beaches.
Creole is widely spoken, alongside Portuguese as the official language.
Cabo Verde has become a popular low-key European winter sun destination.
Tourism focuses on beaches, hiking, and live music rather than mass resorts.
Despite limited resources, Cabo Verde is considered politically stable in the region.
The islands sit on ancient volcanic hotspots, shaping their rugged terrain.
Cambodia is home to Angkor Wat, the world’s largest religious monument and a national symbol.
Angkor Wat appears on Cambodia’s flag, making it one of the few flags with a real building.
Phnom Penh sits at the meeting point of three major rivers.
Cambodia’s cuisine features fermented fish paste that divides visitors instantly.
The country has one of the youngest populations in Southeast Asia.
Traditional Apsara dance is taught from childhood and performed at major ceremonies.
Cambodia has rapidly growing tourism driven by history and temple complexes.
The Khmer language has one of the longest alphabets in the world.
Motorbikes dominate daily transport across cities and rural areas.
Cambodia’s recent economic growth contrasts sharply with its tragic 20th-century history.
Cameroon’s 1990 World Cup run made history as the first African team to reach the quarter-finals.
They famously defeated defending champions Argentina in the tournament’s opening match.
Cameroon is often called ‘Africa in miniature’ due to its diverse landscapes.
The country has beaches, rainforests, savannas, and mountains within one border.
Cameroon is bilingual, with both French and English as official languages.
Samuel Eto’o is one of Africa’s most celebrated footballers.
Mount Cameroon is an active volcano and West Africa’s highest peak.
Cameroon’s music scene blends makossa, bikutsi, and modern pop.
Football matches regularly bring entire cities to a standstill.
The national football team is nicknamed the Indomitable Lions.
Canada has more lakes than the rest of the world combined.
The country stretches from the Atlantic to the Pacific and into the Arctic.
Hockey is culturally mandatory, even if you’ve never skated.
Canada produces global pop stars like Drake, The Weeknd, and Justin Bieber.
The maple leaf is a national symbol and aggressively protected brand asset.
Canada has six different time zones and wildly different climates.
French and English are both official languages at the federal level.
The country has one of the world’s longest coastlines.
Toronto is one of the most multicultural cities on Earth.
Canada is famous for politeness, but also very serious winters.
The Cayman Islands are a major global financial hub despite their small population.
They’re famous for Seven Mile Beach, consistently ranked among the world’s best.
The islands have no direct taxes, attracting international businesses.
Stingrays regularly interact with tourists at Stingray City sandbars.
The Cayman Islands are a British Overseas Territory.
Scuba diving here is known for clear water and dramatic drop-offs.
English is the official language, spoken with a Caribbean lilt.
The islands sit on a submerged mountain range.
Tourism and finance dominate the local economy.
Cayman cuisine mixes Caribbean flavors with international influences.
The Central African Republic is one of Africa’s most resource-rich yet economically challenged countries.
Large areas remain sparsely populated and heavily forested.
Bangui, the capital, sits along the Ubangi River.
The country contains significant rainforest biodiversity.
French and Sango are official languages.
Wildlife includes forest elephants and lowland gorillas.
Much of the country’s infrastructure remains underdeveloped.
Diamond mining plays a major role in exports.
The landscape transitions from savanna to dense jungle.
Despite challenges, local culture remains resilient and community-focused.
Chad is named after Lake Chad, once one of Africa’s largest lakes.
The lake has dramatically shrunk over recent decades.
Chad stretches from Sahara Desert to tropical wetlands.
It has more than 200 ethnic groups.
French and Arabic are both official languages.
Much of Chad is sparsely populated desert.
Nomadic lifestyles remain common in northern regions.
Livestock herding is central to rural economies.
Chad has no coastline, increasing transport challenges.
Its geography makes it one of Africa’s most diverse countries.
Chile is one of the longest north-south countries on Earth.
It stretches from the Atacama Desert to Patagonia’s glaciers.
The Atacama is considered the driest desert on the planet.
Chile produces world-famous wines and exports them globally.
Santiago sits between mountains and vineyards.
Easter Island, with its moai statues, belongs to Chile.
Chile regularly experiences earthquakes due to tectonic activity.
The Andes dominate much of the country’s eastern border.
Chile has a strong astronomy presence thanks to clear skies.
Patagonia’s landscapes look like they were designed by a fantasy author.
China is the world’s most populous country, with over a billion people.
It spans deserts, rainforests, mountains, and megacities.
The Great Wall stretches thousands of kilometers across northern China.
China’s high-speed rail network is the largest in the world.
Beijing combines imperial palaces with futuristic architecture.
Chinese cuisine varies dramatically by region.
China is the birthplace of paper, gunpowder, and printing.
The country has rapidly grown its space exploration program.
Mandarin is the most spoken language globally.
China’s influence shapes global manufacturing and trade.
Colombia is the only South American country with both Pacific and Caribbean coastlines.
It is one of the world’s most biodiverse countries.
Shakira is one of Colombia’s most famous global exports.
Colombian coffee is internationally celebrated for quality.
Bogotá sits high in the Andes mountains.
The country has dramatically improved security over recent decades.
Colombia produces colorful festivals and vibrant street culture.
Medellín is known for urban innovation and transformation.
The Amazon rainforest covers much of southern Colombia.
Music styles like cumbia and vallenato originated here.
Comoros is a small island nation off Africa’s east coast.
It sits between Madagascar and mainland Africa.
The islands are volcanic and visually dramatic.
One volcano remains active on the main island.
Comoros has strong cultural ties to East Africa and Arabia.
French and Arabic influence the local culture.
Fishing plays a major role in daily life.
The country has one of Africa’s smallest populations.
Cloves and vanilla are important export crops.
Comoros remains relatively unknown to mass tourism.
The Cook Islands are a self-governing territory in free association with New Zealand.
They consist of 15 islands spread across a huge ocean area.
Tourism focuses on lagoons, snorkeling, and slow island life.
Rarotonga is the main island and transport hub.
The islands are named after Captain James Cook.
Local culture emphasizes dance, drumming, and storytelling.
Many residents hold New Zealand citizenship.
The islands are surrounded by coral reefs.
Population numbers are small and tightly knit.
Cook Islands culture remains strongly Polynesian.
Costa Rica abolished its army in 1948.
It is famous for rainforests, volcanoes, and wildlife.
Sloths are a national unofficial mascot.
The phrase ‘Pura Vida’ is used constantly and means everything.
Costa Rica produces a large share of renewable energy.
It has coastlines on both the Pacific and Caribbean.
Ecotourism is a major economic driver.
The country has a long-standing stable democracy.
National parks cover roughly a quarter of the country.
Costa Rica consistently ranks high for happiness.
Croatia has a stunning Adriatic coastline with over a thousand islands.
Dubrovnik doubled as King’s Landing in Game of Thrones.
Croatia’s national football team regularly overperforms expectations.
The country has Roman ruins alongside medieval cities.
Croatia popularized the modern necktie, originally worn by soldiers.
Plitvice Lakes National Park is known for cascading waterfalls.
The Dalmatian dog breed originates from this region.
Croatia blends Mediterranean and Central European cultures.
Tourism surges during summer months.
Croatian cuisine varies greatly by region.
Cuba is famous for classic cars still driving Havana’s streets.
The country is known for cigars, rum, and salsa music.
Havana’s old town is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Cuba has one of the world’s highest literacy rates.
The island played a major role in Cold War history.
Baseball is more popular than football in Cuba.
Cuban music has influenced jazz and Latin pop worldwide.
The island has diverse ecosystems beyond beaches.
Cuba is the largest island in the Caribbean.
Colorful architecture defines many Cuban cities.
Curaçao is a Caribbean island with brightly colored Dutch architecture.
It is part of the Kingdom of the Netherlands.
Willemstad’s waterfront looks like a pastel painting.
The island is famous for blue Curaçao liqueur.
Curaçao lies outside the main hurricane belt.
Papiamento is widely spoken alongside Dutch and English.
The island has excellent diving and snorkeling sites.
Its culture blends European, African, and Caribbean influences.
Curaçao has a dry, sunny climate.
The island has a long history of trade.
Cyprus is located at the crossroads of Europe, Asia, and Africa.
It is associated with the mythological birthplace of Aphrodite.
The island is divided into two politically distinct areas.
Cyprus has a long history of Greek and Roman influence.
